newsitem.title: UK: London gold dozes ahead of holiday weekend.
newsitem.headline: London gold dozes ahead of holiday weekend.

text.p: Gold prices stagnated in a tiny range on Friday, unruffled by strong U.S. durable goods figures which sent bonds in a tailspin.
Bullion fixed unchanged from the morning fixing at $387.50 an ounce, against $387.00 on Thursday afternoon.
Dealers said they were preoccupied with squaring their books ahead of the market holiday on Monday in Britain and Hong Kong.
Comex December gold was unchanged at $392.50 an ounce, after trading in an early $392.10-$392.70 range.
The market ignored a surprising 1.6 percent rise in U.S. July durable goods orders, against an expected 0.3 percent rise.
The data caused bonds to tumble and shares were also expected to come under pressure.
Analysts said the jump suggested the manufacturing sector was growing gradually and the economy was holding on to some of its second-quarter strength.
Gold and silver had popped a little higher on Thursday on New York-driven buying funds and locals following the Bundesbank's cut in a key money market rate.
Analysts said that easier global monetary policy might encourage demand for precious metals in the medium term. But dealers said it had had virtually no immediate effect.
Summer lethargy, along with upcoming over-the-counter options expiry on Wednesday, were behind gold's statis in a narrow $386-$388 range, dealers said.
"We have OTC options expiring on Wedneday and a long weekend ahead. Gold's been in a narrow range and I don't think anyone sees it moving up in the next few days," a dealer said.
Silver was indicated unchanged from Thursday's London close at $5.23/$5.25 an ounce. Bids were between $5.24 and $5.20.
Like gold, it was expected to stay within its $5.15-$5.25 range near term after failing in an attempt to break past key resistance at $5.25-$5.26 on Thursday afternoon.
But silver's rally at the start of the week, which took it well above previous resistance at $5.15, was keeping the market slightly on edge.
"It's high enough to have to come back, but there's a slimmer chance of it going up and if we break through $5.27, we'll see $5.35," a dealer said.
Platinum was unchanged from Thursday's close at $398.75/$399.75, but off the day's modestly firmer highs.
